heisigComment: * As a primitive, this character can also mean to drop.
heisigStory: "To lose" here takes the sense of "misplace," not the sense of defeat, whose kanji we learned in frame 67. It pictures a husband with something falling from his side as he is walking along, something he loses.
koohiiStory1: The drop falling here is the husband´s toupee... he´s already lost his hair once, now he´s losing it again. Such is life, I suppose.
koohiiStory2: Note: Heisig´s stroke order is wrong. It´s the same as vermilion, drop first. Homer loses/drops his wedding ring.
myStory: thua. lỗi. sai. chồng mọc sừng
words:
失格(しっかく): disqualification, elimination, incapacity (legal)
失調(しっちょう): lack of harmony
損失(そんしつ): loss
紛失(ふんしつ): losing something
失う(うしなう): lose, part with
過失(かしつ): error, blunder, accident
失業(しつぎょう): unemployment
失望(しつぼう): disappointment, despair
失恋(しつれん): disappointed love, broken heart, unrequited love, be lovelorn,
失敗(しっぱい): failure, fail
